required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Performance of Two Oxygen Delivery Devices Used After General Anesthesia.
clinical_study.official_title: The Performance Comparison of Two Oxygen Delivery Devices [Nasal Cannula and Mask] Used After General Anesthesia.

brief_summary.textblock:
After general anesthesia, there are the risks for airway obstruction, hypoventilation, atelectasis, ventilation-perfusion mismatch, hypercarbia and hypoxemia,so oxygen supplement in PACU seems necessary.
This study aim is to compare the two methods of oxygen supplement which are 1.nasal cannula at O2 flow 4 L/min. 2.oxygen mask with O2 flow 5 L/min. The hypothesis in this study is the 2 methods can equally provide effective oxygen supplement to prevent anesthesia-related hypoxemia. Choosing nasal cannula would be reasonable because it is cheaper and more comfortable to patient.

detailed_description.textblock: The incidence and causes of hypoxemia in PACU will be identified, if necessary, a higher flow or changing oxygen delivery system can be used to prevent and treat hypoxemia. If any patients fail from oxygen weaning protocol in PACU and need longer oxygen therapy at ward, the duration of oxygen therapy will be recorded and also the compliance with oxygen delivery devices.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Hypoxemia in Both Groups
primary_outcome.description: Hypoxemia is defined as oxygen saturation < 94%. We record number of participants with hypoxemia in both groups

secondary_outcome.description: Causes of hypoxemia in each participant in PACU will be recorded

arm_group.description: Oxygen mask with oxygen flow 5 L/min will be given to allocated post general anesthesia patients. The incidence and causes of hypoxemia will be recorded.
Oxygen cannula with oxygen flow 4 L/min will be given to allocated post general anesthesia patients. The incidence and causes of hypoxemia will be recorded.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- General anesthesia
- Age 18-70 years
- American Society of Anesthesiology (ASA)physical status 1-3
- Elective case
Exclusion Criteria:
- ASA physical status class 4 or more
- Unstable pulmonary diseases
- BMI > 35 kg/m2
- oxygen saturation < 94% when breathing in room air
- Respiratory muscle weakness eg.myasthenia gravis
- Central nervous system abnormalities eg.drowsiness, hypoventilation
- Patients who have been intubated or needed ventilatory support before operation
- Plan to remain intubated after the operation
- Intracranial, intrathoracic and upper abdomen surgery
- Patients who nasogastric tube is inserted
- Airway problems eg. sinusitis
- Nasal cavity related surgery or nasal packing eg. endoscopic sinus surgery
- Patient refusal

group.title: Oxygen Mask
group.description: Oxygen mask with oxygen flow 5 L/min will be given to allocated post general anesthesia patients. The incidence and causes of hypoxemia will be recorded. oxygen mask

group.title: Oxygen Cannula
group.description: Oxygen cannula with oxygen flow 4 L/min will be given to allocated post general anesthesia patients. The incidence and causes of hypoxemia will be recorded. oxygen cannula

participants_list.participants: One patient in oxygen mask received oxygen cannula
1 patient in oxygen cannula group receive oxygen mask

baseline.population: Patients aged between 18-70 years who were scheduled for elective surgery under general anesthesia and had American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status 1-3.

reported_events.time_frame: 1 hour after anesthesia (in post-anesthesia care unit)
reported_events.desc: Adverse events such as hypoxemia, re-intubation, unplanned ICU admission will be recorded. There were no serious adverse events.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
